title: Charging - 2 grounded spheres and negative rod

content.description: An experimental setup involving two conducting spheres is shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> hangs by a flexible metal wire from a conducting fixture, and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> rests on an insulating stand. There are two wires that are both connected to ground. One of the wires is near, but not touching, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and the other wire is attached to Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Initially, all the experimental components are electrically neutral.
content.question: In each of two experiments a negatively charged, insulating rod is brought near the conducting fixture holding Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> becomes attracted to Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. In Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the rod is then moved away from the spheres. In Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the wire near Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is briefly touched to Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and then removed. Finally, the rod is moved away. In which experiment do the two spheres remain attracted to each other after the rod is moved away, and what is the cause of the attraction?

choices.label: Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> that was repelled by the rod is attracted to the positive charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> that was repelled by the rod moves to the fixture, leaving a positive charge on Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> that is then attracted to the negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Negative charge leaves Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> through the grounding wire. This gives Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> a net positive charge, so it is attracted to the negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The grounding wire causes the fixture-Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> system to become neutral. When the rod is moved away, negative charge moves from Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to the fixture, and remaining positive charge on Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is then attracted to negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

content.answer: Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Negative charge leaves Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> through the grounding wire. This gives Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> a net positive charge, so it is attracted to the negative charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
